latestVersion.restrictions:
Authorized users of the Washington State University Stowell database are currently enrolled students of Washington State University or of other non-profit public or private colleges and universities; and faculty and researchers currently employed by or affiliated with Washington State University or other non-profit public or private colleges and universities.

The collection may only be used for educational and related research purposes: the education and instruction of students, resea rch activities related to such education and instruction, and other research by Washington State University or other non-profit public or private colleges and universities.

If a party wishes to use the collection for commercial purposes, said party must execute a separate agreement with Leigh Stowell & Company. Commercial uses shall mean any purposes or uses other than educational and related research purposes including without limitation any services that result in the payment or collection of a fee.

Authorized users must:

a) Authenticate and authorize themselves using methods for doing so provided on the Washington State University Libraries Stowell server.

b) Read and agree to the conditions of use posted on the Washington State University Libraries Stowell server.

c) If enhancing data retrieved from the Stowell datasets by adding new data for a geographic locality or localities, provide Washington State University with a digital copy of that new data in a standard format specified by Washington State University at the time of enhancement so that the new data will be ava ilable to all subsequent Authorized Users.

d) Not remove any copyright and other such proprietary rights notices placed on the data that they retrieve and use for publication or dissemination to other Authorized Users.

e) Not disseminate data from the Stowell datasets to unauthorized users unless they have executed a separate agreement to do so with Leigh Stowell & Company.

f) Cite the source of the data that they use in the form described on the Washington State University Stowell Database Website.
latestVersion.citationRequirements:
In all publications and reports entailing the use of the Washington State University Libraries' Leigh Stowell Datasets, please use the following:

Data access services provided by the Washington State University Libraries to: Leigh Stowell and Associates US and Canadian Media Market Studies Digital Archive at Washington State University, organized and maintained by the Division of Governmental Studies and Services, College of Liberal Arts, Washington State University.
latestVersion.depositorRequirements: Authorized Users must cite the source of the data that they use in the form described on the Washington State University Stowell Database Website.

fields.value: Stowell Datasets Digital Archive: Columbus, Ohio, USA

authorName.value: Leigh Stowell & Company, Inc., Seattle, Washington, United States

dsDescriptionValue.value:
This is one of over 400 major media market consumer surveys which have been gifted to Washington State University (WSU) by Leigh Stowell & Company, Inc. of Seattle, Washington, USA. This is a market research firm which specializes in providing newspapers, television affiliates and cable operators with market segmentation research pertinent to consumer purchasing patterns and the effective marketing of goods and services to program audiences. The data in the Stowell Archive were collected via random digit dialing and computer-aided telephone interviews (CATI). Most of the surveys focus on the marketing needs of mass media clients and contain demographics, psychographics, media exposure information, and purchasing behavior data about consumers in major metropolitan areas of the United States and Canada starting in 1989. The sample sizes of the surveys range from 500 to 3,000 respondents, averaging 1,000 observations per study. Data are available at the respondent level, and all observations are keyed to zip code or other geographic identifiers. Additional surveys are anticipated, with over twenty new media marke t studies being donated annually.

The University's relationship with Leigh Stowell & Company, Inc. was cultivated by Dr. Nicholas Lovrich, Director of WSU's Division of Governmental Studies and Services (DGSS) and by Dr. John Pierce, former Dean of the WSU College of Liberal Arts over the course of a decade.

DGSS collaborated with WSU Libraries Digital Services to process the gifted data files into this digital archive which features powerful search and download capabilities. Further refinement of the archive in accordance with the Data Documentation Initiative is progressing with support from the Office of the Provost, the College of Liberal Arts and the WSU Libraries.

It is important to note that the year indicated by the study's title is the year that the original survey was published, and is not necessarily the year in which the interviews were conducted. Refer to the metadata field "Dates of Collection" to di scern the interview dates of each specific survey. Refer also to date fields within the data file itself.

publicationCitation.value:
Hendryx, M. S., Ahern, M. M., Lovrich, N. P., & McCurdy, A. H. (2002). Access to Health Care and Community Social Capital. Health Services Research, 37(1), 85-101.

Moon, C. D., Lovrich, N. P., & Pierce, J. C. (2000). Political Culture in Canada and the United States: Comparing Social Trust, Self-Esteem, and Political Liberalism in Major Canadian and American Cities. Social Science Quarterly, 81(3), 826-836.

Moon, C. D., Pierce, J. C., & Lovrich, N. P. (2001). Political Culture in the Urban West: Is It Really Different? State and Local Government Review, 33(3), 195-201.

Pierce, J. C., & Lovrich, N. P. (2003). Internet Technology Transfer and Social Capital: Aggregate and Individual Relationships in American Cities. Comparative Technology Transfer and Society, 1(1), 49-71.

Pierce, J. C., Lovrich, N. P., & Moon, D. C. (2002). Social capital and government performance: An analysis of 20 American cities. Public Performance and Management Review, 25, 381-397.

files.description: The attached questionnaire, transferred into Adobe PDF file format, is an unedited Leigh Stowell and Company, Inc.   working file from which the Computer Aided Telephone Interview (CATI) instructions were derived. It includes   question "skip sequences" (for example, if respondent answers "yes" to question #x, then skip to question #y) not   shown elsewhere. Note that all other available interviewer instructions are listed at the data variable level.
files.label: Columbus_1998_QNR.pdf

dataFile.description: The attached questionnaire, transferred into Adobe PDF file format, is an unedited Leigh Stowell and Company, Inc.   working file from which the Computer Aided Telephone Interview (CATI) instructions were derived. It includes   question "skip sequences" (for example, if respondent answers "yes" to question #x, then skip to question #y) not   shown elsewhere. Note that all other available interviewer instructions are listed at the data variable level.

files.description: The original methodology text provided to Stowell and Company, Inc.’s client is not available for all media market   studies. The following “generic” documentation is provided in lieu of or to augment the original methodology text.   This information was extracted from Stowell and Company, Inc.’s market research reports. Since some of the Stowell   media market studies did not include psychometric questions, the sections entitled “Values Selection Design,” “Value   Profile Analysis,” and “Attitude Dimensions” may not apply to this survey.
files.label: Generic_METHOD.pdf

dataFile.description: The original methodology text provided to Stowell and Company, Inc.’s client is not available for all media market   studies. The following “generic” documentation is provided in lieu of or to augment the original methodology text.   This information was extracted from Stowell and Company, Inc.’s market research reports. Since some of the Stowell   media market studies did not include psychometric questions, the sections entitled “Values Selection Design,” “Value   Profile Analysis,” and “Attitude Dimensions” may not apply to this survey.
